ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Kill all the rolls
ResponsesInList.Text: ummm... At this point there is no way to delete multiple instances of a single module at once. I may be able to shoehorn this one in somewhere, but I'm not sure, since module instances are managed at a higher level than the module is implemented. It's the responsibility of the course management code to add and delete instances. I'll look into that. As for groups, there's no concept of 'grouped' instances in moodle... yet. I've heard that that's coming in a future version. As for why they're mixed up, I've not seen this before. They should be sorted by date and time. If they're not, then you may have to set them all to be automatically assigned to sections based on date, which is an option for each attendance instance. The presence list is filled in by the instructor. It can also be filled in automatically, based on the logged activity by each student. This is a feature that can be turned on for each attendance as well. Russ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: View by week report added
ResponsesInList.Text: The reason the attendance instances are visible to the students is because there's a special view available to students that shows just their attendance record, while hiding all the others. As for a topic based course, when you add instances to a topic based course it behaves in a similar way to a week-based course. When you add a single instance it sets the date to what you've chosen it to be, but ignores the 'dynamic placement' option, leaving it in the section you created it in. If you create multiple, it will create them in the range specified by the start date of the course and the number of topics, I think. I could add a preference that allows you to create the instances as hidden by default, if that would help your situation. Russell Jungwirth

ResponsesInList.Title: Grading now implemented
ResponsesInList.Text: Grading is now implemented for attendance. A setting for whether to grade the roll is there do determine if it should apply. If it is set, then the value for maximum grade is used to determine a grade for the each student based on the overall percentage of the time he was present. It takes into account the number of hours in the roll as well as how many tardies are equivalent to a single absence. Remember tardies per absence is set for the entire site, and is set in the settings for the module. Incidentally, there are also default settings for grading new attendances and for the maximum grade default value. Okay. I've done enough work in this for the day. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attendance Roll for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: I do have user-definable settings for this module. From the top level of your moodle site, go into TOP -> Administration -> Configuration -> Modules There you'll find a 'settings' link for my module, once it's been installed. I don't have an option there for setting a student as absent by default, but I will add one. The rationale behind only storing records for tardy and absent is scalability. The number of records in that table would get very big very fast if I stored records for all 'present' students. Therefore, I simply use the rule of 'if no record for the roll, then count as present', since in the average course the vast majority of students will be present most of the time.

Please note that just creating a new roll and not editing it does not set the values to the default. Instead, they remain marked as 'present' for that roll until you edit it for the first time. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attendance Roll for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, this might be an artifact from my importing a previously-created attendance roll into Moodle's attendance module...but... When re-editing an attendance record that has already been submitted, I've noticed that the radio buttons on the edit form end up at the default setting, and not the previously entered value. For example: My attendance default is set to Absent (A). John Doe is marked Present (P) on 3 September 2003, but when I edit the roll for that date, everybody (including John Doe) has their radio button set as 'A'. I cancel the edit, view the attendance for that day, and confirm that John Doe was Present. Enter the edit for that day, and everybody is set to 'A' again. Repeat ad infinitum... Is this how a 'clean' recordset (i.e., one not created by non-standard SQL import) also behaves? Or have I really botched something up someplace...? AND, BTW , how can I turn off the feature that treats attendance as a gradeable assignment?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attendance Roll for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: The short answer is that this is how I've designed it to work. If you save the changes to an instance, it will save the proper settings for each student for each hour of the roll. The long answer: Read a couple of replies up - you'll see that as long as you haven't saved changes to an attendance roll, the roll stays marked as all 'present' until you edit it the first time - at that edit it sets all the defaults to the preference setting you chose in settings for the default attendance. This is done to allow all your rolls to be added at once at the beginning of the course - but still to allow the ones that haven't been edited yet to *not* affect the overall attendance totals. Once you edit a roll for the first time and save the changes, it is assumed that you're taking roll for the course for that day, and you're interested in convenience and speed for editing the roll (thus the default setting of all to one status - absent, or tardy say) and then once you've saved the roll ,you want it to affect the overall attendance totals for the course. If I were to set all the attendance instances to the default as soon as they were created, and not at the first save, the overall totals for attendance rolls would be useless, as students would be counted as 'absent' or 'tardy' for days that haven't even come up yet in the course. Consider it as a compromise between ease of use in creating multiple attendance instances at once and ease of use in actually using those instances later to take roll on the day it was created for. Does that make sense?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attendance Roll for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Um. Kind of. But once I've actualy set the roll, say a student that was not present when roll was taken shows up...at that point, I need to go back and edit his/her roll for that day. But then I'd need to remember which were present and which were not from the listing, because when I go to the edit page, all of those changes are not shown. When I wrote the attendance feature for my own LMS (which I'm considering abandoning production for in preferene of Moodle), I made it so that the db query accurately showed the roll as stored in the database ...I set up a switch scenario that put 'checked' in the radio button HTML code as the page is generated so that each button set for each student reflects their stored settings. It makes sense to have the first view of the roll page show up with the default settings, but each edit after that really ought to be based on what's actually stored in the db. Otherwise, edits to accurately update one student's attendance run the very real risk of introducing inaccuracies into the rest of the class... Does that make sense? *grin*

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attendance Roll for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: um... that's definitely not working right then. It should be storing the student's proper status after the first edit of a given instance. It works the way you expect it to on my test site. Odd. I'll have to check the code again. Maybe check your mdl_attendance table to make sure that there is a field there called 'edited' If not, run this code in mysql : ALTER TABLE `mdl_attendance` ADD `edited` TINYINT( 1 ) DEFAULT '0' NOT NULL; UPDATE `mdl_attendance` set `edited` = 1; replacing 'mdl_' with your prefix if it's different.
